subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the
leading edge
of knowledge and discovery with
parapsychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, and welcome. I’m Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today I'm going to talk a bit about my
grandfather Abraham Rogow, my mother's father, because I think
of my four grandparents he probably had
the strongest influence upon me. In fact,
certainly had the strongest influence
upon me
and in many ways I'm like him.
He was a dreamer, he was a pioneer, he was
an adventurer.
I'm showing you now a picture of my grandfather
and grandmother and the aunts and uncles,
his children
and my cousins. There I am. The two twins
are my cousins Mark and Steve
Roberts and I'm sitting next to my
grandmother in my mother's lap. It's
1947. I'm about one year old.
My grandfather was born in the town of
Bialystock. Today it's in Poland but when
he grew up it was really a Russian
city. He grew up
speaking a number of different languages.
At that time he knew German, he knew
Polish, he knew Russian. I think they were all
essential - and Yiddish because the Jewish
people spoke Yiddish. Bialystok at the time was
largely a Jewish town. I think,
if I recall the statistics correctly it
had, well at the time of the Second World
War I think a population of 90,
000 people - 70,000 of whom were Jews,
most of whom were killed in the
Holocaust. But
fortunately for my grandfather he got
out of there long before.
In fact, as I understand it there was a
pogrom, which is an event where the
natives - in this case the local
people of Bialystok -
attacked and killed about 80 Jews and
that happened
shortly before he left for Palestine
at the age of 16 to become a pioneer.
Now, one of the reasons - to change
gears a little bit here - one of the
reasons I wanted to talk about my
grandfather has to do
with the video that is to be released
the day before
this monologue will be released.
That's the discussion with my friend Jason
Reza Jorjani on the end of humanity,
the end of history, the end of reality.
Jason is forecasting,
in effect - and many people along with him
are forecasting - a singularity,
a unique event in human history
after which everything will be different,
dramatically different.
Well, I think there's something to it. We
don't know exactly
when it will happen, exactly how it will
happen. In fact,
that's the whole point of the
singularity. Once you're on the
other side of it everything is so different
it's not even recognizable. But as I look
at my grandfather's
life, he grew up
in an era where everybody was driving
horses and buggies
if they had transportation in that part
of the world.
The horse and buggy was the common
mode of transportation. He lived
to see a man walk on the moon
in 1968 [correction, 1969]. I remember
visiting his home in Bayonne, New Jersey
and talking to him
about that. So my grandfather has seen
enormous changes in his own lifetime
and things have only been accelerating
since then.
Now, I can't say that I agree or disagree
with Jason's
vision of the future, other than yes
there are going to be radical changes. But
how to best adjust to those changes,
that's an issue for deep thought. I
think Jason raises very provocative
questions and
although it's tempting sometimes to
think, “No,
things, no matter how much they change,
they'll always be the same,
humans will always be humans.”
[That] may not be the case. Jason is suggesting
the end of humanity as we know it
could be within the next 30 years.
Well, back to the story of my grandfather.
As I say, he grew up in Bialystok. His
family were merchants, it was a textile
city. So his family engaged in the
textile trade.
I'm under the impression they were
pretty prosperous.
They sent their daughters, my
grandfather's older sisters, to
Switzerland
to be educated which was unusual both in
terms of going so far away for the
education but the very idea of
educating the daughters at all in a
Jewish family in that period
was quite unusual. My first cousin, Steve
Roberts, his father changed the family
name from
Rogo to Roberts, I suppose you could
say as an adroit
move politically and for business sense.
My cousin Steve has written a couple of
books about the family
and writes extensively about my
grandfather who is
a real character.
I didn't know my grandfather as well as
my cousin
Steve because Steve grew up in Bayonne,
New Jersey
with him. I grew up in Wisconsin
so I saw him only occasionally.
But every time it was quite special.
I have to say
that he was a wonderful grandfather.
He wrote to my cousin Steve
and Steve quotes him in the book at a
time when he left
Russia to go to Palestine and became a
pioneer. I have a photo of him I'm going to show it right
now. Here he is working, building what was
to be the second
road ever built in Tel Aviv, Israel.
He's about 16 years old at the time
working on a very primitive highway crew.
He wrote that his first
job in Israel was to
guard a vineyard at night and how he
loved to look out at the sky
at night. He said, yes, we had beautiful
stars in Bialystok but in the desert in
Palestine in those years - we're talking 1907 I believe -
the sky was brilliant. He just
loved to be out there at night looking,
every night was
different. He felt he was communing
with the stars.
I love to do that today here in New
Mexico where I live
up at 6,000 feet near the Sandia Mountain
where I can look at the sky at night
from my deck.
I feel the same feeling my grandfather
must have felt.
Interestingly, he helped me
encourage my interest in astronomy. When
I was 12 years old he bought me a telescope.
In fact, I got a second telescope from
him when I
visited him at the age of 18.
He used to get me all of these crazy
things. He bought me a geiger counter
at one time. He went to a carnival
and he found these machines that
spin around and you squirt
paint on them and create beautiful
images and he bought me one of these
paint spinning machines.
He bought me a movie camera at
one time, an old eight millimeter movie
camera.
He bought me my first car, as a
matter of fact,
a pink and white Chrysler New Yorker.
So he was always kind of
probing. He was ahead of the game
in his own way. He read The New York
Times religiously
and made a point of discussing the news
with family members. I understand
in my mother's household growing up they
were arguing politics
over the dinner table every night.
He was an entrepreneur. He became
a carpenter, he built houses.
Here's a picture of the house he built
that he lived in
at 31 Lincoln Parkway in Bayonne, New
Jersey,
right adjacent to
Newark Bay,
looking out across the bay to Newark, New
Jersey. He had a trailer park, that was his big
success in business, running a trailer park. But
before that he had
many other adventures. They didn't always
turn out so well. He had an amusement
park at one time.
He had a boxing ring. He had
gambling. I think he was involved a
little bit in the illegal gambling business.
He was also a thoughtful man. He
published a pamphlet on world federalism
and even though he himself was, as he put
it, a humble carpenter,
he liked to think in global terms.
Now, he was also something of a mystic
in his own way. I remember when I visited
him in 1968. I was
in my early 20s, I think. I was about 22
at the time
and drove out to New Jersey to see my
grandfather, well and visit New York.
Bayonne is right across the Hudson River
from Manhattan so you're practically
as close to Manhattan as people might be
living in Brooklyn.
I was reading at the time
a book by P.D. Ouspensky, In Search of the
Miraculous, and I mentioned it to my
grandfather,
this is what I'm reading. He said, “Oh
yes, Ouspensky.”
He knew of Ouspensky. I think he had
probably been reading Ouspensky as a
young man himself in Russian.
One of my last
meetings with my grandfather, he
became a little bit senile towards
the end of his life. He lived to be
85. One of the last times I visited him
he said to me, “Jeffrey, I've invented
a new word.”
He loved to invent things, he was an
inventor. I said, “Oh, what is it?” He says, “It's not
billions, it's not millions, it's not
trillions,” he says, “it's illions,
illions.” And I said, “Oh,
okay illions. That's a very big number
if it's illions.” He said, “Yes.” He said,
“When I die,” he said, “I'll be illions of
miles away from you
but you can always reach me.” I
said, “Oh, how can I do that?”
And he grabbed my hand like this and he
scratched it right there in the middle
of the palm like that.
He said, “Whenever you want to connect
with me you just scratch your palm just
like this and I'll be there.”
That has always stuck with me.
I felt really connected to my grandpa
ever since then. And I feel that,
sometimes when I'm out at night looking
up at the stars in the sky I scratch
my palm and think, “Grandpa, you're still
here.”
Well, let me leave you with this question.
Who amongst your ancestors has been
a strong influence in your life? How did
they influence
you? Can you sense in your own
personality and your own
makeup, your drives, your desires, your
longings,
the influence of the people, the older
members of your
family, your ancestors?
I'll leave you with that thought.
And let me leave you with another
thought. How do you think the world will
yet change in your lifetime? What changes
do you expect to see in your
lifetime? So I'll leave you with those
thoughts.
Thank you for being with me.
[Music]
